text: In my opinion, the devasting loss against T&T was primarily Bruce Arena’s fault. I could understand his decision to use three forwards (namely Altidore, Woods, and Pulisic) as well as defensively weak Nagbe in the Panama match because (1) the Americans were playing on their home soil, (2) a win against Panama was essential, and (3) the Americans needed to score as many goals as possible because goal-differential was a tie breaker.  Once Arena got what he wanted from the Panama match, selecting the same lineup in the T&T game was madness.  Not only was the T&T match an away game, all that was now needed was a 0:0 tie.  Nagbe may be the worst left midfielder in the last 3 decades I’ve been following the USA team.  There are times he looks really good moving forward. Having said that, he disappears for long stretches of most matches. That’s why Klinsmann didn’t like him.  Not only does Nagbe refuse to play defense, when he moves forward from the left side of the field he always goes to his right thereby clogging up the middle of the field making it easy for T&T to defend in front of their goal.  I suspect that the reason why Nagbe always does this is because he can’t cross the ball.  When he’s on the field, there is no width to the team. Worse, he leaves the left side of the mid field exposed when he moves into the center of the field.  Taylor Twellman and Adrian Healey pointed out how exposed Bradley was in the Panama game due to Nagbe’s poor defensive abilities and his tendency to leave his position. Both warned that an adjustment was needed for the T&T match, especially since all that was needed was a tie.  Give the T&T coach credit seeing how open Nagbe’s part of the field was.  Both T&T goals were started from their right side, attacking the hole on America’s left were Nagbe should have been.  Finally, I can’t really blame Nagbe. He is what he is.  He’s not going to change.  Arena should have started a more defensive midfielder.  That was his first blunder.  At least he should have seen what was going on before T&T scored  their first goal.  That he didn’t pull Nagbe until a few minutes before the end of the match was his second blunder.

Klinsmann lost to Mexico and Costa Rica.  Arena tied in Honduras and lost to T&T.  You be the judge.  Would Germany have played for a tie against T&T or any other football nation?  I think not.  T&T outplayed a timid team with more talent. How can a team play for a tie against T&T? There was too much on the line for the US to play such spiritless football.  I felt sorry for Pulisic.  He is a great player with little to play with.  Dempsey showed heart but came in way too late.  I believe Gulati should resign as well as Arena.  Start fresh. There is excellent talent in the US mostly playing outside the MLS (smart move).  MLS stands for Masters (old people) League Soccer not Major League soccer.

Hats off to T&T.

context_meta.summary: By Babak Dehghanpisheh BEIRUT (Reuters) - Iran's moderate president gave a full-throated defense of his one-time rivals in the Revolutionary Guards on Wednesday, as the country's pragmatist and hardline factions rallied together in the face of threats from Donald Trump. The U.S. president is expected to "decertify" Iran's nuclear deal with global powers this week and add its Revolutionary Guards military force to Washington's black list of terrorist groups under a strategy to increase pressure on Tehran. The threat of U.S. action has united the two main factions of Iran's leadership, with the pragmatists led by President Hassan Rouhani who seek greater openness to the West demonstrating their support for the hardline Guards.

context_meta.title: How the U.S. Lost the War in Syria to Russia and Iran
context_meta.summary: When the U.S. and its allies finally began their offensive to defeat the Islamic State militant group (ISIS) in the eastern Syrian province of Deir Ezzor in August 2017, the Syrian battlefield looked very different to when the conflict began in 2011. Back then, President Barack Obama came out in support of rebels trying to overthrow Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and, in 2012, began arming them. In the years since, America's friends and foes have shifted, however, and its leading rival, Russia, stepped in to help Syrian President Bashar al-Assad quell a nationwide rebellion and reclaim the lion's share of his country.

context_meta.title: U.S. SEC moves to simplify corporate compliance paperwork
context_meta.summary: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission proposed rules on Wednesday to simplify the disclosures that publicly traded companies must file with the agency when communicating with investors. Republican U.S. President Donald Trump has vowed that his administration will cut red tape for businesses and SEC Chairman Jay Clayton endorsed the proposed rules at his first open meeting on Wednesday. "I am supportive of today's proposal because it would make some modest and marginal changes to our disclosure framework," said Commissioner Kara Stein, the only Democrat on the three-person SEC panel.

context_meta.title: Editorial: The United States deserved to lose
context_meta.summary: This has been a long time coming. The United States' elimination from the upcoming World Cup in Russia is an unmitigated disaster for soccer in this country. There are a ton of reasons why the next four to at least eight years is going to suck as an American soccer fan, most of which were laid out in this article by Kevin McCauley. But while this is a nadir for the United States, it is absolutely deserved on every single level by every single person. This is a system that was designed to fail, whose backers were blinded by obtuse loyalty regardless of faults and whose detractors were all too often focusing on the wrong things. No, promotion and relegation would not have prevented this any more

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Morgan Freeman: Mankind Will Perish If We Don't Learn to Live Together
context_meta.summary: From the political upheaval in America, to the refugee crisis in Europe, and the Rohingya crisis in Myanmar, we are living in turbulent times. In a new six-part National Geographic docuseries, The Story of Us, Freeman seeks out answers to how we as one world can co-exist. Over the course of the episodes, which touch on themes of love, power, freedom, peace, rebellion and social division, Freeman speaks to extraordinary people from all over the world, including former U.S. President Bill Clinton and President Paul Kagame of Rwanda, a country that has experienced immense healing after years of civil war.

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: OPEC Secretary General urges U.S. shale oil producers to help cap global supply
context_meta.summary: OPEC's Secretary General Mohammed Barkindo on Tuesday called on U.S. shale oil producers to help curtail global oil supply, warning extraordinary measures might be needed next year to sustain the rebalanced market in the medium to long term. The comments by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries official came during a speech delivered at the India Energy Forum organised by CERAWeek in New Delhi. "At the moment we (OPEC and independent U.S. producers) both agreed that we have a shared responsibility in maintaining stability because they are also not insulated from the impact of this downturn," Barkindo said, referring to a slide in oil prices that spurred OPEC to agree production cuts late last year.

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Cambodia's Hun Sen renews criticism of United States amid escalating row
context_meta.summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen on Wednesday renewed his criticism of the United States, a week after a leading opposition figure fled the country over fears of a widening crackdown on government critics ahead of next year's election. Hun Sen, who has ruled Cambodia for more than 30 years and shows no sign of wanting to relinquish power, has forced the closure of several English-language media and jailed government critics, including opposition leader Kem Sokha. Bombs recently discovered at nine sites in southeastern Svay Rieng province had been dropped by the United States during the Vietnam war, Hun Sen said in a speech to workers at garment factories that export most of their output to the U.S. "These bombs dropped on Cambodia belong to the United States," Hun Sen said in his latest comments in a growing row over his accusations that American agents conspired with Kem Sokha to overthrow the government.

context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: U.S., Russia in extradition tug-of-war over bitcoin fraud suspect in Greece
context_meta.summary: A Greek court on Wednesday backed the extradition to Moscow of a Russian citizen who also faces being sent to the United States on allegations of laundering billions of dollars in bitcoin. Alexander Vinnik, the suspected mastermind of a $4 billion bitcoin laundering ring, is one of seven Russians arrested or indicted worldwide this year on U.S. cybercrime charges. Judges ruled last week that he should be extradited to the United States, a decision Russia criticized as unjust and illegal and which Vinnik is challenging at Greece's supreme court.
